description:
On 26 January 2021, the Finnish Government issued a Government Resolution for supplementing the action plan implementing the hybrid strategy for combating the COVID-19 epidemic. The supplement to the action plan describes three tiers to prevent the outbreak from escalating and, in particular, to curb the spread of COVID-19 variants:
- Group leisure activities for children under 12 years of age should not be restricted. However, in tier 2, it is recommended that indoor leisure activities for those under 12 years of age comply with the criteria laid down in the guidelines for safe and secure leisure activities.
- Each leisure activity group always meets in the same composition. This means that the group should not take part in competitions, concerts, performances, shows or other situations in which the group comes into contact with other leisure activity groups. Teachers, instructors and coaches should also always be the same ones. Parents may not spend time in their children’s leisure activities and dressing rooms.
- In most facilities, the number of participants should be limited to 10 people. In big gyms and other large spaces, it is possible for separate groups of 10 people to exercise without any contact between the groups.
- In tier 1, there are no restrictions for group leisure activities outdoors or in restricted outdoor areas. However, when tier 2 is reached, group leisure activities in restricted areas outdoors should follow the recommended procedures.

description:
On 6 February 2021, restrictions were announced for food and beverage service businesses in North Korelia, Lapland, and South Savo, which will remain in force until 30 June 2021:
- Policy changed to allow food and beverage businesses up to 75% capacity to and open between the hours of 1:00 and 24:00. 
- Alcohol primary businesses may allow up to half capacity and open between the hours of 24:00 and 23:00. Alcohol may only be served between the hours of 7:00 and 22:00.

description:
On 6 February 2021, tighter restrictions were announced for food and beverage service businesses in Uusimaa, Southwest Finland, Kanta-Häme, Päijät-Häme, Kymenlaakso, Ostrobothnia and North Ostrobothnia, regions that have reached the community transmission phase, which will remain in force until 30 June 2021: 
- Food and beverage service businesses that primarily serve alcoholic beverages will be allowed to serve alcohol between 7.00 and 22.00, be open between 5.00 and 23.00, and will be restricted to 50% capacity.
- In other restaurants, the serving of alcoholic beverages will be permitted between 7.00 and 22.00, they may be open between 5.00 and 23.00, will be allowed to seat 75% of their normal number of customers.

description: On 13 March 2021, the Finnish government enacted a new decree which restricts the activities of food and beverage service businesses due to the COVID-19 epidemic. With the amendment, the restrictions that previously applied to regions in the community transmission phase of the epidemic would be introduced throughout the country. The decree would now apply to areas where restaurants are allowed to remain open, i.e. those not affected by the lockdown. These include Kainuu, North Karelia, Central Ostrobothnia and North Savo. The amount of customer seating in restaurants that primarily serve alcoholic beverages will be restricted to half the normal number of seats. For other restaurants, 75 per cent of customer seats may be in use. Restaurants may serve alcoholic beverages until 22.00 and may be open between 5.00 and 23.00.

description: On 6 June 2021, Finland's nonessential businesses are permitted to open with restrictions on operating hours and the number of customers allowed inside the establishment at a time. Authorities have permitted catering establishments to reopen subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements. Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks. Timeframe expected from 6 June 2021 until 28 June 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 17 March 2020, the Finnish government announces exceptions made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act, in both the private and public sector, to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare to perform work as necessary. If necessary, the employer is allowed to suspend of postpone the employee's leave and can also deviate from the obligation to obtain consent for the employee to work overtime. The employer can also extend the notice period to four months, if a shortage of labour, due to the coronavirus, is imminent.

description: On 20 March 2020, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health "issued guidelines to municipalities on the operation of primary health and social services, including general guidance on rehabilitative work carried out under the responsibility of the municipalities. According to the guidance, the obligation to organise health and social services continues even in emergency conditions, and the municipalities must ensure their clients’ right to receive services in accordance with individual needs. Because of the risk of infection, group activities arranged in the same physical space are not possible now. During the coronavirus outbreak, rehabilitative work may include, for example, online coaching, remote tasks, individual guidance, and activities in workplaces where there is no risk of infection." These recommendations are valid until 31 July 2020.

description: On 30 April 2020, the Ministry of Transport and Communications submitted a bill to Parliament to temporarily amend the Driver's License act so that "driving licenses of people over 70 could be renewed so that the medical certificate required for renewal would be delivered to the police no later than 31 October 2020. The same practice would also apply to the renewal of driving rights for heavier vehicles and traffic instructor licenses for people over 45 years old...The changes would be valid for a period of a few months, but no later than" 30 April 2021.

description: On 30 April 2020, the Finnish government submitted proposals to Parliament temporarily amending transport laws. The notification period for providers of passenger transportation services would be shortened from 60 days to five days. The proposal would make it possible for public transport operators to change, for example, their schedules faster than at present, and thereby adapt their business to changing conditions." The policy will remain in place until no later than 30 April 2021.

The rental of meeting and assembly facilities is possible in compliance with the restrictions on public events of the Regional Administrative Agency of Southern Finland. Indoors, the use of a face mask is recommended for people over the age of 12.

description: On 1 July 2021, the indoor sports facilities managed by the city will also open for limited exercise use by adults. This applies, for example, to the free use of gymnasiums and sports halls, as well as indoor exercise hobbies for adults. A maximum of half of the normal number of customers can be admitted to exercise facilities and group exercise. Adult competitive activities related to hobbies are also allowed indoors from July 1st . The activity must comply with the health and safety guidelines for hobby activities.

description: On March 24 2020, Finland's Ministry of the Interior launches the #virutaaliveappu campaign, which encourages people to celebrate the annual vappu event, which marks the end of winter, at home. The campaign gives Finns alternative ways to spend vappu together through quarantine concerts and sima tasting on the sofa. Social media influencers are also taking part in spreading awareness. Vappu is traditionally celebrated together with friends and family outdoors.

description: On 23 April, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs Health announces that the national Mother's Day celebration will not be held on 10 May. This year, the award ceremony of conferring a Medal First Class with Gold Cross to mothers for their merits as educators will take place at a date to be announced later.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 14 May 2020, the Finnish government announces that public events with a maximum of 50 persons may be held in indoor and outdoor premises. Public meetings include demonstrations and other events that are open to all and that are organised in line with the right to freedom of assembly. Public events include entertainment events, competitions, performances or other similar events that are open to the public. The use of public sports facilities or visiting a shopping centre, for instance, do not constitute public meetings or public events
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
"On June 11, the Finnish government updates its policy on outdoor events and say that the permitted number of attendees may exceed 500 persons if:
- event attendees can be placed in their own seating areas of viewing sections, each of which has a maximum capacity of 500 persons, with the ability to maintain safe distance and by providing hygiene instructions
- a clear buffer zone is arranged between each viewing section, have its own access routes, services (food/beverage/sanitary), event staff"

description: On 12 March 2020, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health advises the Regional State Administrative Agencies to prohibit all events with over 500 attendees until the end of May, under the Communicable Diseases Act. UPDATE: On 11 June, the Finnish government makes specifications to policy on audience sizes at outdoor events as of 1 July, 2020. For outdoor events where there are several sections or demarcated areas intended for audiences, a total audience of more than 500 persons may be permitted starting on 1 July with special separation arrangements.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 15 May 2020, the Ministry of Education and Culture and the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare has decided that all public events with more than 500 attendees are prohibited, without exception, until 31 July. UPDATE: On 1 July, the government clarified its policy regarding the number of visitors to outdoor events. Now, it is possible to have an outdoor event with a total audience of more than 500 people with segregation arrangements.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 11, 2020, Finnish Government makes announces that as of 1 July, the number of attendees at public events in enclosed outdoor spaces is still restricted to 500. However, for outdoor events where there are several sections or demarcated areas intended for audiences, a total audience of more than 500 persons may be permitted starting on 1 July with special separation arrangements. The policy is in effect until July 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 14 May 2020, the Finnish government announces that public events with a maximum of 50 persons may be held in indoor and outdoor premises. Public meetings include demonstrations and other events that are open to all and that are organised in line with the right to freedom of assembly. Public events include entertainment events, competitions, performances or other similar events that are open to the public. description:
On June 11, the Finnish government updates its policy on outdoor events and say that the permitted number of attendees may exceed 500 persons if:
- event attendees can be placed in their own seating areas of viewing sections, each of which has a maximum capacity of 500 persons, with the ability to maintain safe distance and by providing hygiene instructions
- a clear buffer zone is arranged between each viewing section, have its own access routes, services (food/beverage/sanitary), event staff. UPDATE: On 31 July 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will lift restrictions on public events

description: Finnish authorities have announced stricter coronavirus disease (COVID-19) measures to be imposed in the Helsinki region for three weeks from Monday, November 23, as efforts continue to combat an increase in the number of virus infections. Indoor public meetings of more than 20 people will be banned. Adults' team and contact sports will be suspended, with amateur-level matches and competitions canceled during this time. Individual and group sports competitions on the national team, national and Division I levels, and professional athletes training for international competitions, as well as group activities which maintain social distances, will be exempt.

description: On November 1, 2020, Regional State Administrative Agency for Southern Finland, Finland, rules that those mass gatherings of over 20 people in the Kanta-Häme Hospital District can only happen if extreme care is taken in hygiene and social distance measures. This policy is in effect until 30 November 2020. UPDATE: On November 18 2020, the policy was extended to last until December 31 2020. Additionally, while the original policy targets events of more than 20 people, the extended policy targets only events of more than 50 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: the Kanta-Häme Hospital District
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On November 1, 2020, Regional State Administrative Agency for Southern Finland, Finland, rules that those mass gatherings of over 20 people in the Kanta-Häme Hospital District can only happen if extreme care is taken in hygiene and social distance measures. This policy is in effect until 30 November 2020. UPDATE: On December 1 2020, the qualitative nature of the original policy is changed. When the original policy only limited mass gatherings of over 20 people in setting certain conditions to them, the updated policy directly bans all public mass gatherings of over 10 people. It should also be noted that the planned extended policy supposed to last to the end of December 2020 limiting mass gatherings of more than 50 people was never implemented. Instead, it was determined that the Kanta-Häme Hospital District has moved to the Community transmission phase of the epidemic, and thus the stricter policy was enacted at the start of December.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: the Kanta-Häme Hospital District
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
"On 29 April, the Finnish government announces new guidelines and instructions for childhood education and childcare facilities. The guidelines include:
- avoidance of unnecessary physical contact
- arranging teaching premises more spacious than usual
- school break times and school meals must be held with the student's own class or group
- no large gatherings, such as spring festivals
- personnel must work with the same group of children and hygiene guidelines must be strictly respected

The school year is set to end on 30 May.

description:
On 16 March 2020, the Finnish government bans visits to housing services for the elderly and other at-risk groups as well as care institutions, with the exception of asymptomatic family members of critically ill individuals and family members of those in hospice care, who will be permitted to visit on a case-by-case basis'. UPDATE: On June 17 2020, the Finnish government announces that units providing 24-hour care and treatment must provide their older clients and others belonging to risk groups with the opportunity to meet their loved ones safely, by ensuring adequate protection in an outdoor location or by arranging separate, protected, meeting facilities.

As a general rule, the government recommends that access to premises providing 24-hour care and treatment remain limited to staff.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On 26 May, the Finnish government announced a new set of regulations for rehabilitative work, overriding the previous policy that was set back in April. Beginning from 1 June, municipalities are to open their rehabilitative work facilities, including work activity centres, group-based social welfare services, group activities in social rehabilitation, or work and day activities for people with disabilities. Many municipalities closed their facilities when the government banned gatherings of more than 10 persons on 16 March, the national government encourages municipalities to reopen and use their discretion in deciding which alternative forms of rehabilitative work are offered.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Private health offices
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 17 2020, the Finnish government announces the removal of the restriction that barred visits to hospitals and primary healthcare units. The government says that a cautious approach must be taken when arranging visits and that the operating unit is in charge of making practical arrangements, such as the use of PPEs and appropriate meeting places.Units providing 24-hour care and treatment must provide their older clients and others belonging to risk groups with the opportunity to meet their loved ones safely, by ensuring adequate protection in an outdoor location or by arranging separate, protected, meeting facilities.As a general rule, the government recommends that access to premises providing 24-hour care and treatment remain limited to staff.

description: On 18 April, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and health says that they do not recommend the use of medical face masks or fabric masks when moving in a public place for the general population. In its statement, the Ministry says that the respiratory protective equipment should be necessary for health care personnel openly and that the use of self-made fabric masks in public places 'may, at worst, lead to a false sense of security'. description: Finnish government announced on October 1, 2020 that mask use is no longer mandatory, but now recommended extensively. In the regions where the infection rates are highest, in the so-called "spreading phase" (according to the Finnish classification of regions into 3 types: basic, accelleration, spreading), the recommendation includes:   - Always on public transport including taxis.  - Always in public spaces and events, including schools and educational institutions from year 7 upwards.

description: The Finnish government has issued new border traffic restrictions and travel recommendations on November 6, 2020 and continues to ask that all residents avoid non-essential travel. Citizens should avoid non-essential travel on public transport at peak hours, so that those who have to travel can do so safely. Walking and cycling are encouraged as an alternative.  Passengers are also encouraged to wear face masks when taking public transportation.

description:
On 23 November 2020, Finnish authorities imposed stricter COVID-19 measures in the Helsinki metropolitan area and the whole of Uusimaa until 13 December 2020:
- Indoor public meetings of more than 20 people will be banned.
- Swimming halls, gyms, and other sports venues, cultural centers, museums, and libraries will remain open with social distancing rules applied and limits on capacities.
- Organizers of sports and cultural events, as well as private events, remain encouraged to recommend face mask usage.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 17 2020, the Finnish government announces the removal of the restriction that barred visits to hospitals and primary healthcare units. The government says that a cautious approach must be taken when arranging visits and that the operating unit is in charge of making practical arrangements, such as the use of PPEs and appropriate meeting places.Units providing 24-hour care and treatment must provide their older clients and others belonging to risk groups with the opportunity to meet their loved ones safely, by ensuring adequate protection in an outdoor location or by arranging separate, protected, meeting facilities.As a general rule, the government recommends that access to premises providing 24-hour care and treatment remain limited to staff. UPDATE: On 24 November 2020, the Finnish government updates its policies regarding visits to residential care units.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on patients leaving nursing home/long term care facility
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
The Region of Kymenlaakso, Finland, bans all visits in many of its health care providers including hospitals of Pohjois-Kyme, Karhula, and Hamina as well as in the rehabilitation center Hoikku from 30 November 2020 until 31 December 2020. 

This decision does not apply to the psychiatric hospital of Kymenlaakso, palliative care units of Villa Apila and Villa Meri, child ward, or the support persons for mothers in labor. Exceptions are also made for individuals that are in a critical state or near-death.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 1 March 2021, the Finnish government temporarily amended the Communicable Diseases Act which would extend the validity of the provisions on restrictions concerning food and beverage service businesses until 30 June 2021. Food and beverage service businesses would have to follow specific hygiene requirements and be able to maintain sufficient physical distances between customers, draw up a plan on how to implement the restrictions and obligations, and the plan and the maximum permitted number of customers would have to be displayed where customers can see them.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 3rd May 2021,in the city of Helsinki, primary and secondary schools  must stagger starting times and lunches, in addition to ensuring safe distances and the practice of good hand hygiene. in the event that a coronavirus infection is discovered in an early education establishment, school or other educational institute, those exposed will be traced and quarantined. remote teaching must be arranged for all of the students who have been judged to be exposed.

description: Coronavirus instructions for Elderly people -     Helsinki - Residents of senior centres, assisted living facilities and nursing homes may be visited by their relatives and close friends once a day. Two visitors at a time are allowed for indoor visits. Five visitors at a time are allowed for outdoor visits. An indoor or outdoor visit may last up to an hour.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On 13 May, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues new guidelines for facilities providing 24-hour care and treatment. These guidelines include that staff who come into close contact with patients must wear disposable surgical nose-masks or washable or disposable fabric masks that cover their nose and mouth in order to protect against any disease.

description: On 6 June 2021, Finland's nonessential businesses are permitted to open with restrictions on operating hours and the number of customers allowed inside the establishment at a time. Authorities have permitted catering establishments to reopen subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements. Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks. Timeframe expected from 6 June 2021 until 28 June 2021.

description: Residents of senior centres, assisted living facilities and nursing homes in Finland may be visited by their relatives and close friends once a day as of February 22, 2021. Only one visitor is allowed at a time. Two visitors at a time are allowed for outdoor visits. As of 22 February, an indoor or outdoor visit may last up to an hour. All visits must be agreed on in advance with the care facility of the relative, and face masks must be used during the visits.
